definition[0]: a structure made of wood, metal, plastic etc that surrounds something such as a picture or window, and holds it in place
example[0]: They removed the picture from its wooden frame.
definition[1]: the structure or main supporting parts of a piece of furniture, vehicle, or other object
definition[2]: the general shape formed by the bones of someone’s body
definition[3]: the metal or plastic part of a pair of glasses that holds the lenses
definition[4]: the main ideas, facts etc that something is based on
example[3]: A clear explanation of the subject provides a frame on which a deeper understanding can be built.
example[4]: Some comments may or may not be understood as harassment, depending on your frame of reference  (=knowledge and beliefs that influence the way you think).
definition[5]: an area of film that contains one photograph, or one of the series of separate photographs that make up a film or video
definition[6]: a complete part in the games of snooker or bowling
example[5]: I won the next three frames.
definition[7]: one of the areas into which a webpage is divided
definition[8]: to surround something with something else so that it looks attractive or can be seen clearly
example[6]: Sarah’s face was framed by her long dark hair.
example[7]: She stood there, framed against the doorway.
definition[9]: to put a picture in a structure that will hold it firmly
example[8]: I’m going to get the picture framed.
definition[10]: to deliberately make someone seem guilty of a crime when they are not guilty, by lying to the police or in a court of law
example[10]: Needham’s lawyers claimed that he had been framed by the police.
example[11]: The two men were framed for murder.
definition[11]: to carefully plan the way you are going to ask a question, make a statement etc
example[12]: She wondered how she was going to frame the question.
definition[12]: to organize and develop a plan, system etc
example[13]: Newman played a central role in framing the new law.
